Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with straight sides; underside decorated with representation of falcon and three indistinct signs (hieroglyphic ones? including maybe a Was sign) above neb-basket sign; hard to tell if motif is incised or stamped; pierced through diameter; glaze mostly gone; in pale yellow paste; very eroded surface.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (probably)
Curator's comments: The hieroglyphic inscription on its underside does not seem to make sense. The hieroglyphs are probably used here for their magical value as often for this type of scarab (Gorton 1996, 93). Falcon is a common theme on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory” and appears on various composition (on productions of the Scarab Factory, see Webb forthcoming). This scaraboid belongs to a type that was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 99, 106-107, type XXVIII A, subtype 149-158, see especially no. 151 for this piece). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 51)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 99, Type XXVIII A151)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.022) (phase 3)
